articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez
articles.description:
Can we make pie chart that's semantic, with flexible markup, and avoids using a JavaScript library? Here's how I tackled it.
Trying to Make the Perfect Pie Chart in CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Trying to Make the Perfect Pie Chart in CSS

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
CSS-only bar charts are one of those things we've tackled a bunch of times in different ways. But how can modern CSS features finally make it not only trivial, but fun?
CSS Bar Charts Using Modern Functions originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Bar Charts Using Modern Functions

articles.author: Zell Liew
articles.description:
You’d think that publishing a VS Code extension is an easy process, but it’s not. You have to publish your theme in at least two places.
No Hassle Visual Code Theming: Publishing an Extension originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: No Hassle Visual Code Theming: Publishing an Extension

articles.author: Zell Liew
articles.description:
I've always thought that creating a VS Code theme was a lot of work. But lo and behold, it took less than six hours to get it working, then a day or two to polish up my final tweaks.
No-Hassle Visual Studio Code Theming: Building an Extension originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: No-Hassle Visual Studio Code Theming: Building an Extension

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
Neither Chrome, Safari, nor Firefox have shipped new features in the last couple of weeks, but fear not because leading this issue of What’s !important is some of the web development industry’s best educators with, frankly, some killer content.
What’s !important #4: Videos & View Transitions, Named Media Queries, How Browsers Work, and More originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What’s !important #4: Videos & View Transitions, Named Media Queries, How Browsers Work, and More

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
The new ::search-text pseudo (Chrome 144) matches are yellow while the current target (::search-text:current) is orange, but ::search-text enables us to change that.
Styling ::search-text and Other Highlight-y Pseudo-Elements originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Styling ::search-text and Other Highlight-y Pseudo-Elements

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Stu Robson's ReliCSS (clever name!) tool can excavate outdated CSS in your codebase that have modern CSS solutions.
ReliCSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: ReliCSS

articles.author: Zell Liew
articles.description:
Accessibility advice around modals have commonly taught us to trap focus within the modal. Upon further research, it seems like we no longer need to trap focus within the <dialog> (even in modal mode).
There is No Need to Trap Focus on a Dialog Element originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: There is No Need to Trap Focus on a Dialog Element

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
A while back, Temani tacked a repeating grid of hexagon shapes. Well, he's updated it with modern CSS features that result in fewer magic numbers. And it's impressive!
Responsive Hexagon Grid Using Modern CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Responsive Hexagon Grid Using Modern CSS

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The @custom-media at-rule has landed in Firefox Nightly! I couldn’t find it in the release notes but Adam Argyle’s on the beat noting that it’s behind a flag for now.
Look for layout.css.custom-media.enabled
I often forget the exact name of …
Open Props @custom-media Recipes originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Open Props @custom-media Recipes

articles.author: Hashim Quraishi
articles.description:
Semantic HTML does a lot more accessibility work than we usually give it credit for already — and ARIA is simple to abuse when we use it both as a shortcut and as a supplement.
I Learned The First Rule of ARIA the Hard Way originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: I Learned The First Rule of ARIA the Hard Way

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I love me some good web research reports. I’m a sucker for them. HTTP Archive’s Web Almanac is one report I look forward to every year, and I know I’m not alone there. It’s one of those highly-anticipated publications on …
HTTP Archive 2025 Web Almanac originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: HTTP Archive 2025 Web Almanac

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
If you’re reading this, chances are you already have some sort of way that you’re following when we publish new content, whether that’s RSS, Bluesky, Mastodon, or what have you. But I know a lot of folks …
“I Heart CSS” DailyDev Squad originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: “I Heart CSS” DailyDev Squad

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
The developer community hasn’t wasted any time kicking off 2026 with some really great articles, demos, and insights. Firefox 147 and Chrome 144 also shipped, and while they’re not jam-packed with features, the releases are still pretty exciting for what’s normally a slow time of year, so without further ado, here’s what’s important from the last couple of weeks (or should I say the first couple of weeks, of 2026?)…
What’s !important #3: Popover Context Menus, @scope, New Web Platform Features, and More originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What’s !important #3: Popover Context Menus, @scope, New Web Platform Features, and More

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Super cool new CodePen feature alert! You've probably seen a bunch of "interactive" demos that let you changed values on the fly from a UI panel embedded directly in the demo.
Playing With CodePen slideVars originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Playing With CodePen slideVars

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Blake Lundquist)
articles.description: Prescriptive class name conventions are no longer enough to keep CSS maintainable in a world of increasingly complex interfaces. Can the new `@scope` rule finally give developers the confidence to write CSS that can keep up with modern front ends?
articles.title: CSS @scope: An Alternative To Naming Conventions And Heavy Abstractions

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Combobox vs. Multi-Select vs. Listbox vs. Dual Listbox? How they are different, what purpose they serve, and how to choose the right one. Brought to you by Design Patterns For AI Interfaces, **friendly video courses on UX** and design patterns by Vitaly.
articles.title: Combobox vs. Multiselect vs. Listbox: How To Choose The Right One

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s make the most of the shortest month of the year with a new collection of desktop wallpapers that are sure to bring a smile to your face — and maybe spark your creativity, too. All of them were designed with love by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Happy February!
articles.title: Short Month, Big Ideas (February 2026 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stefan Kaltenegger)
articles.description: AI coding tools like agents can be valuable allies in everyday development work. They help handle time-consuming grunt work, guide you through large legacy codebases, and offer low-risk ways to implement features in previously unfamiliar programming languages. Here are practical, easy-to-apply techniques to help you use these tools to improve your workflow.
articles.title: Practical Use Of AI Coding Tools For The Responsible Developer

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Gabriel Shoyombo)
articles.description: In CSS, we can create “stacking contexts” where elements are visually placed one on top of the next in a three-dimensional sense that creates the perception of depth. Stacking contexts are incredibly useful, but they’re also widely misunderstood and often mistakenly created, leading to a slew of layout issues that can be tricky to solve.
articles.title: Unstacking CSS Stacking Contexts

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Yocco)
articles.description: Developing effective agentic AI requires a new research playbook. When systems plan, decide, and act on our behalf, UX moves beyond usability testing into the realm of trust, consent, and accountability. Victor Yocco outlines the research methods needed to design agentic AI systems responsibly.
articles.title: Beyond Generative: The Rise Of Agentic AI And User-Centric Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Amit Sheen)
articles.description: Amit Sheen takes a hard look at the “Pixel Perfect” legacy concept, explaining why it’s failing us and redefining what “perfection” actually looks like in a multi-device, fluid world.
articles.title: Rethinking “Pixel Perfect” Web Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: CSS relative colour values are now widely supported. In this article, pioneering author and web designer [Andy Clarke](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/) shares practical techniques for using them to theme and animate SVG graphics.
articles.title: Smashing Animations Part 8: Theming Animations Using CSS Relative Colour

articles.description: Hiring the right candidate starts with one time-consuming task: screening résumés. If you’ve ever posted a job opening, you know the pain of hundreds of applications in your inbox, leaving you to spend hours reviewing each résumé manually. In this ar...

articles.description: Modern applications rarely live in isolation. They move between laptops, staging servers, and production environments. Each environment has its own quirks, missing libraries, or slightly different configurations. This is where many “works on my machi...

articles.description: In the world of big data, performance isn't just about bigger clusters – it's about smarter code. Spark is deceptively simple to write but notoriously difficult to optimize, because what you write isn't what Spark executes. Between your transformatio...

articles.description: Feature flags are powerful tools that let you control which features are visible to users without deploying new code. They enable gradual rollouts, A/B testing, and instant feature toggles, which are all essential for modern software development. In ...
articles.title: How to Build a Production-Ready Feature Flag System with Next.js and Supabase

articles.author: Oluwadamisi Samuel
articles.description: Your UI doesn’t “randomly” refuse to update. In most cases, it’s rendering cached data, which is data that was saved somewhere so the app doesn’t have to do the same work again. Caching is great for performance, but it becomes a pain when you don’t r...
articles.title: Why Your UI Won’t Update: Debugging Stale Data and Caching in React Apps

articles.description: Harvard University's CS50 is one of the most popular beginner computer science courses in the world. We just released the entire 25-hour CS50 course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel. This is the most recent version updated for 2026, with an al...
